@wlockhart  because they're still college students regardless...

@domenickeller2189  College students at one of the best universities in the world. If they were accepted into Cambridge (for example) they'd be able to do Taylor's theorem in their sleep, and they would be chastised by their tutors for repeatedly asking if something is on the exam, rather than reading widely. Don't have such low standards and expectations. They're not schoolchildren and they're not lightweight.
@wlockhart  come on, they are just joking
@immortalspiritualbeing7037  Thanks for letting me know. This whole time I thought they were being serious.

@wlockhart  This is a general class, which includes biology majors, business majors and several other majors which are not necessary as mathematically skilled.  MIT offers several versions of multivariable calculus for students to choose, at MIT ocw you can find the following 3 versions:  18.02 - The easiest version. This class is typically taken by less math intense majors or by those who didnt do advanced placement calculus BC in high school.  18.022 - A version of the course for more math based STEM fields.  18.024 - This can basically be considered the honors version of the course. This class is more abstract and focuses more on proofs than the other 2. This will typically be taken by students who got prizes in math olympiads in high school, or by brave math majors.
